summary:
I am an inquisitive, result-driven chemical/process engineer. 

After doing an Internship at Jacobs in the process engineering department during my bachelor studies, I choose to do my masters in chemical engineering in the process track at Delft University of Technology in the Netherlands. Through my masters i have developed a diverse technical skillset such as thermodynamics, process development and scale-up, fluid flow, process analysis, unit operations to name a few. I have also been developed skills to work with Matlab, Simulink and ASPEN simulation software.

My peers and supervisors have often described me as Pro-active, structured and result-oriented.

Apart from academics, I am passionate about running, badminton and cooking. I also keep myself updated about current events, and particularly like to read about International relations and politics.

projects:
[{'title': 'Designing Nano-emulsions to influence crystallization kinetics', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'description': 'Crystallization is a common method with a long history for producing solid products in the chemical
and pharmaceutical industry. Yet surprisingly, nucleation which is the initial step of crystallization is
poorly understood. One of the reasons for this difficulty is the fact that it is impossible not to have
hetero-nucleants (so called impurities) in solutions that ultimately induce nucleation. This has motivated
increased interest for research in studying and improving understanding of nucleation in recent
years by studying these hetero-nucleants. 

Contributing towards this goal an attempt is made to design these
impurities in a way so that we can control their properties and functions. This is done by exploring
the possibility of using liquid-liquid interfaces, which is nanoemulsion in this case, to induce heterogeneous
nucleation. 

The nucleation kinetics of two model compounds, KCl and d-Mannitol have been
established based on induction time experiments. Furthermore, a second system of nanoemulsion was
prepared and its stability was studied. The induction time experiments were repeated in the nanoemulsion
system and the effects were studied. Oil fraction in the nanoemulsion was observed to affect the
overall kinetics and experiments. Ultimately, evidentiary support was established that the presence of
nanoemulsion enhanced nucleation in a certain range of induction time by 28%.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Mehul', 'last_name': 'Jain', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Process/Chemical Engineer'}]}, {'title': 'Large scale protection (coating) of organic pigments', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}}, 'description': 'Conducted a Total cost of ownership (TCO) analysis of a new process proposed by Delft IMP (startup in Delft) for large-scale protection of pigment from lab-scale. Delft IMP has already demonstrated protection of such materials on small-scale in a project together with DSM, whereby applying a nanometer thick coating on these pigments resulted in a tailorable paint surface finish. The remaining challenge is to scale up the proposition from lab scale to production scale which I explored along with 4 other colleagues.

The activities conducted includes process study, PFD, P&ID, material and energy balances, reactor design, safety study, HAZOP and economic analysis.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Mehul', 'last_name': 'Jain', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Process/Chemical Engineer'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Ymke', 'last_name': 'Van Zwet', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Strategy advisor at Eigen Haard | Illustrator'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Joane', 'last_name': 'Villar Gimeno', 'name': None, 'headline': 'R&D Manager at Aislantes Sólidos - Ormazabal | Chemical Engineer'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Yael', 'last_name': 'Althuis', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Manufacturing Technology Process Engineer bij The Chemours Company'}]}, {'title': 'Using Peanut shells as organic media in Biofiltration for wastewater purification', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}}, 'description': "Peanut shells as a cheap, easily available source of organic media for biofiltration process was explored. The project started with an extensive survey of the Biofiltration process and different media possibilities for the process. This was followed by a study of the water quality parameters and kinetics of the microbial growth.

Thereafter, a trickling filter setup was created and several experiments like COD,BOD on the in-stream and out-stream line were conducted. The project concluded with modelling, and costing. The project also consisted of a plant visit to a nearby water purification plant.

Significant reduction in important water quality parameters like BOD, COD (85% in COD, 66% in BOD), while it's short-life was noted as it's disadvantage. ", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Mehul', 'last_name': 'Jain', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Process/Chemical Engineer'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Harnish', 'last_name': 'Naik, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Johns Hopkins University | Biologics Drugs Process Development | Life Sciences/Healthcare Strategy Consultant'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Gwynneth', 'last_name': 'Borges', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Process engineer at Editas Medicine'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Azhir', 'last_name': 'Barodawala', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Senior Sales Engineer at Tesla'}]}]
